description: Tree works subject to a Tree Preservation Officer.T1 LBI (No.245) 2002. False Acacia - fell because of rotting caused by fungus growth.
decision_conditions:
The application to fell the tree has been refused for two reasons:

(i)	on the basis of loss of a visual amenity and 
(ii)	on the basis that the agent has failed to supply sufficient evidence to satisfy the Council that the tree requires removal. 


Loss of visual amenity
The tree contributes materially to the amenities of the locality, playing an important part in providing a sense of scale, maturity and textural diversity to the immediate vicinity.

The tree is situated within the Barnsbury Conservation area and the council deemed this tree worthy of the implication of a TPO in 2002. The level of amenity provided since the imposition of the TPO has not declined.

Level of evidence
We do not currently have the level of evidence we require to allow this tree to be removed. Further investigation may be appropriate, including the non invasive decay detection techniques. 
The reason given by the agent for the removal of this tree:

1)	Rotting caused by fungus growth (Pholiota squarrosa)
2)	Risk of wind throw


Rotting caused by fungus growth
It is alleged that the tree has a fungal infection by the wood decay fungus Pholiota squarrosa – This is a common fungi on Robinia.

Photocopy submitted with the application as evidence of the identification is from Watson & Green (2011) Fungi on Trees Arboricultural Association.

No samples of the fungi have been sent for positive identification and no photographic evidence has been submitted identifying the location of the fruiting body to T1. 

I agree with the assessment provided that P. squarrosa ‘can become extensive enough to cause failure’. In this instance there is no evidence of extensive decay. The site investigation failed to find any evidence of fungal ingress or resulting reaction by the tree.

The assessment provided by the agent also outlined that:

‘The decay can become extensive enough to cause failure, and so the stem base and principal roots should be inspected in detail in high-usage localities. However, adaptive growth often compensates adequately for loss of stiffness and hollowing.’

So the assessment made by the agent states that extensive decay may cause failure but adaptive growth often compensates adequately for the loss of stiffness and hollowing.



Risk of wind throw
The condition of the tree has no obvious symptoms that correspond with the tree being at risk from wind throw.

Even if a proportion of decay is found the removal of a tree is often not the most appropriate management. Trees may co exist with fungal decay for many years without undue risk. A common method of management for trees with an established decay fungi ( dependant on species of host and parasite) is the crown maintenance and regular inspection of the tree.  

The risk management of trees infected includes expert investigation, positive identification, regular inspection and possible mitigating tree pruning works.

The council do not currently have the level of evidence we require to allow this tree to be removed. Without evidence of decay the council cannot reasonably permit the removal of this protected tree.
